channel.title: Lecture Videos on MIT OpenCourseWare
channel.description: Recent content in Lecture Videos on MIT OpenCourseWare

item.title: Lecture 1: Introduction to 14.02 Principles of Macroeconomics
item.description: This lecture covers an introduction to the topic of macroeconomics, which is the study of the behavior of an economy as a whole. The instructor also talks about the objectives of the course.

item.title: Lecture 10: Quiz 1 Review
item.description: Prof. Caballero spends this lecture reviewing material for the upcoming quiz.

item.title: Lecture 11: The IS-LM-PC Model
item.description: The IS (Investment Saving), LM (Liquidity Preference - Money Supply), and PC (Philips Curve) model looks at the dynamics of output and inflation. It relates to the central bank policy decision to adjust the inflation and real interest rate in the economy.

item.title: Lecture 12: IS-LM-PC Model continued
item.description: Prof. Cabellero continues the discussion of the IS-LM-PC Model from lecture 11.

item.title: Lecture 13: The Facts of Growth
item.description: Prof. Caballero discusses the concept of growth. Growth is the steady increase in aggregate output over time. He also shifts to talking about growth and determination of output in the long run.

item.title: Lecture 14: Saving, Capital Accumulation, and Output
item.description: Prof. Caballero explains the first model of economic growth and discusses interactions between output and capital.

item.title: Lecture 15: Technological Progress and Growth
item.description: Prof. Caballero explains how technological progress takes many forms: larger quantities of output, better products, new products, and a large variety of products.

item.title: Lecture 16: Convergence and Cross-Country Variation
item.description: Prof. Caballero talks about convergence, when economies of different countries become similar to each other, as well as, variation among different countries.

item.title: Lecture 17: Introduction to Open Economy
item.description: Prof. Caballero introduces the idea of an open economy—the fact that most economies trade both assets and goods with the rest of the world.

item.title: Lecture 18: Quiz 2 Review
item.description: Prof. Caballero reviews topics from previous lectures for the upcoming quiz.

item.title: Lecture 19: The Goods Market in the Open Economy
item.description: Prof. Caballero finishes talking about the goods market in an open economy.

item.title: Lecture 2: Basic Macroeconomic Concepts
item.description: In this lecture, Prof. Caballero discusses basic macroeconomic concepts such as aggregate output, the unemployment rate, and the inflation rate.

item.title: Lecture 20: The Mundell-Fleming Model
item.description: Prof. Caballero introduces the Mundell-Fleming Model, which describes a small open economy.

item.title: Lecture 21: Exchange Rate Regimes
item.description: Prof. Caballero explains exchange rate regimes, which is a way a monetary authority of a country manages the currency in the foreign exchange market. There are two major regime types: fixed and flexible.

item.title: Lecture 22: Financial Markets and Expectations
item.description: Prof. Caballero talks about expectations—how to value things that you expect to receive in the future, and how to compare those things with what you have in the present.

item.title: Lecture 23: Asset Pricing
item.description: Prof. Caballero discusses asset pricing, which describes the relationship between systematic risk and expected return for assets, particularly stocks.

item.title: Lecture 24: IS-LM and Expectations
item.description: Prof. Caballero explains how expectations about future conditions play a big role in the decisions of all economic actors. The basic IS-LM model overweights the present.

item.title: Lecture 25: Quiz 3 Review
item.description: Prof. Caballero covers topics from the last several lectures in preparation for Quiz 3.

item.title: Lecture 3: The Goods Market
item.description: In this video, Prof. Caballero discusses the goods and services markets. Topics include equilibrium output, the composition of aggregate determination, and the key mechanism of the interaction between demand, production, and income.

item.title: Lecture 4: The Financial Market
item.description: In this session, Prof. Caballero talks about the concept of interest rates, and how they are set in financial markets.

item.title: Lecture 5: IS-LM Model
item.description: In this lecture, Prof. Caballero explains the IS-LM model, which shows the relationship between interest rates and output in the short run in a closed economy.

item.title: Lecture 6: IS-LM, continued
item.description: In this lecture, Prof. Caballero continues his explanation of the the IS-LM model, which shows the relationship between interest rates and output in the short run in a closed economy.

item.title: Lecture 7: An Extended IS-LM Model
item.description: Prof. Caballero discusses an extended IS-LM model and introduces the concepts of nominal vs. real interest rates and risk and risk premium.

item.title: Lecture 8: The Labor Market
item.description: Prof. Caballero discusses labor markets, and why they play such a large role in macroeconomics.

item.title: Lecture 9: The Phillips Curve and Inflation
item.description: Prof. Caballero introduces the Phillps Curve, which states that inflation and unemployment have an inverse relationship. Higher inflation is associated with lower unemployment and vice versa.
